title: Preview: Miami at Kent State
text:
Posted: 12:45 p.m. Friday, Oct. 2, 2015 Preview: Miami at Kent State By Mark Schmetzer 
Who : Miami (1-3) at Kent State (1-3). 
When : 3:30 p.m. 
Where : Dix Stadium (25,319), Kent, Ohio. 
Series notes : Miami leads, 47-15-0. 
Stat pack : Miami QB Drew Kummer (38-70, 571 yards, 6 TD, 2 INT); RB Alonzo Smith (38 carries, 163 yards, 2 TD); WR Sam Martin (12 catches, 204 yards, 1 TD); S Brison Burris (35 tackles, 18 solo); Kent State QB Colin Reardon (49-112, 550 yards, 5 TD, 3 INT); RB Traylon Durham (52 carries, 205 yards, 2 TD); WR Kris White (9 catches, 155 yards); S Nate Holley (36 tackles, 17 solo). 
Local flavor : Redshirt freshman DL Davonte James (Springfield High School/West Virginia), Jr. kicker Brad Miller (Vallew View). 
Back-to-back : Golden Flashes junior defensive tackle Terence Waugh was named the Mid-American Conference East Division Defensive Player of the Week on Monday after piling up a career-high 11 tackles, including three sacks and four tackles for losses, in Kent State’s 36-29 double-overtime loss against Marshall. Sophomore cornerback Demetrius Monday earned the same honor the previous week. Waugh leads the Mid-American Conference with 6-1/2 sacks. 
Stoppers : Kent State ranks first in the Mid-American Conference and fourth in the nation in total defense and ninth in the nation in both passing and rushing defense. 
One dimensional : Kent State ranks last in the MAC in total offense, generating an average of just 328.8 yards per game, right below Miami’s 340.5, which is good for 12th place. The Golden Flashes also are last with an average of 163.0 yards passing per game. 
Benched : Safety Nate Holley and cornerback Najee Murray won’t be available after being ejected from the game at Marshall in the second half. Both were penalized for targeting, leading to the ejections. 
Welcome home : Former Kent State quarterback Julian Edelman, now a New England Patriots wide receiver, will serve as grand marshal for the homecoming parade. 
Brainy : NFL.com chose Kent State senior safety Jordan Italiano as the Smartest Player in College Football over the summer. The pre-med/biochemistry major carries a 3.979 grade-point average. 
Quotable : Third-year coach Paul Haynes after Saturday’s loss to Marshall, which followed a 10-7 loss at Minnesota the previous week: “A lot of crazy things happened in this game, and the ball fell their way in the end. It’s heartbreaking because you know you should have won two weeks in a row. Nobody is going to feel sorry for you, though. Now we begin the most important part of our season. If you watched us during the first week there were a lot of questions about how good we will be. Our record may not show it, but we are a better team now than we’ve been since I’ve been here.” More News
